metadata.case_name: Aggrieved Employees v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench held that Special Rules framed by Governor under Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category on seniority-cum-efficiency basis violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

Presidential Order dated 18th October 1975 under Article 371-D aimed at equitable opportunities in public employment; para 5(1) defines local cadre as unit for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion, transfers; para 5(2) allows limited transfers but not promotions.

G.O.Ms. No.72 dated 25.02.1986 and G.O.Ms. No.117 dated 28.05.1986 made UDCs in Labour Dept and Factories/Boilers Dept eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspector of Labour/Factories, held violative by Tribunal and upheld by SC in V. Jagannadha Rao.

G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training (Ser. IV) Dept dated 26.11.1994, amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 09.05.1996, provided Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices and Factories/Boilers Depts eligible for appointment by transfer to post of Assistant Labour Officer (zonal post).
Employees challenged G.O.Ms. No.14 and 22 before Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal, claiming violation of paras 3(3) and 5(1) of Presidential Order.

Tribunal in OA No.6334/1997 partly allowed petitions on 27.03.2003, struck down G.O.Ms to extent providing channel from outside zone, but prospective overruling: no disturbance to actions till 07.11.2001 per V. Jagannadha Rao, no reversion of promoted employees.
Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal's prospective holding; WP No.16890/2006 filed supporting strike down.
High Court on 09.03.2007 allowed WP 6163/6068, set aside Tribunal's prospective application relying on V. Jagannadha Rao as prospective only by SC; dismissed WP 16890/2006.
Review petition WPMP No.3576/2010 filed by appellants (promoted employees not parties before HC), claiming necessary party status, dismissed on 03.11.2010.
Promotions under impugned G.O.Ms made before 07.11.2001; employees held positions for nearly 10 years; further promotions to Asst/Deputy Labour Commissioners.
State affidavit declines creating supernumerary posts for promoted employees.

legal_issues.text: Whether doctrine of prospective overruling can be applied to save promotions made under G.O.Ms No.14/1994 and 22/1996 prior to V. Jagannadha Rao judgment, given law was in flux and promoted employees not parties.
Whether State Administrative Tribunal or High Court can invoke doctrine of prospective overruling.

petitioner_arguments.text: Promoted employees (appellants) were necessary parties to Tribunal and High Court proceedings; absence vitiates judgments; law in flux till V. Jagannadha Rao; invoke prospective overruling to avoid hardship, reversion after 10 years unjust.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Doctrine of prospective overruling; Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan 2002 6 SCC 562

petitioner_arguments.text: Promotions ordered by State, not snatched by employees; no risk at time; reversion causes cascading effect prejudicing juniors.

respondent_arguments.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable only by Supreme Court, not Tribunal or High Court; promotions under invalid rules cannot be saved.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Golak Nath v. State of Punjab AIR 1967 SC 1643; V. Jagannadha Rao 2001 10 SCC 401

respondent_arguments.text: Employees took calculated risk opting for out-of-zone posts; no need for supernumerary posts.

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling originates in Golak Nath; invocable by SC under Art 142 to mould relief for justice; not confined to overruling prior decisions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: SC has discretion to apply prospectively even if lower courts cannot.

court_reasoning.text: Law in flux till V. Jagannadha Rao; promoted employees not impleaded; long tenure (10 years); reversion unjust, cascading effect; State unwilling for supernumerary posts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Circumstances warrant invoking doctrine to save pre-07.11.2001 promotions.

court_reasoning.text: V. Jagannadha Rao dealt with different GOMs (72/117); no bar to prospective application here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Different rules, same principle but equity demands protection.

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling applied; promotions/appointments under impugned GOMs prior to 07.11.2001 protected; no reversion or disturbance.
Only Supreme Court invokes doctrine, but SC can do so in appeal for justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Jagannadha Rao v. State of A.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held transfers including promotional aspects violative of Presidential Order para 5(2); overruled Sadanandam and Satyanarayana Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of A.P. v. V. Sadanandam
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier upheld such transfers; overruled in Jagannadha Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier upheld such transfers; overruled in Jagannadha Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Golak Nath v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: First invocation of prospective overruling in India; parameters laid down.

precedents_cited.case_name: India Cement Ltd. v. State of T.N.
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied prospective overruling to deny refunds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Orissa Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa
Union of India v. Mohd. Ramzan Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Prospective declaration on enquiry report copy.

precedents_cited.relevance: Overruled Golak Nath on amendability but upheld prospective overruling.

precedents_cited.relevance: Doctrine moulds relief for justice under Art 142.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan

Statutory interpretation: what is said and not said.

precedents_cited.case_name: Institute of Chartered Accountants of India v. Price Waterhouse

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso to Art 309 for rules; Presidential Order under 371D prevails per 371D(10); Art 142 for complete justice and prospective overruling.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Public Employment (Organisation of Local Cadres and Regulation of Direct Recruitment) Order, 1975
statutes_cited.relevance: Local cadre unit; limited transfers excluding promotions; violated by GOMs.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside High Court order to extent it struck down Tribunal's prospective overruling; invoked doctrine of prospective overruling to protect all promotions made under impugned GOMs prior to 07.11.2001 judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao case; directed no reversion or disturbance of such employees' service conditions.
outcome.relief_granted: Past promotions saved; no reversion to parent cadre.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked only in matters arising under our Constitution... only by the highest court of the country, i.e., the Supreme Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Parameters from Golak Nath limiting doctrine to SC.

key_quotes.text: "Prospective overruling, despite the terminology, is only a recognition of the principle that the court moulds the reliefs claimed to meet the justice of the case - justice not in its logical but in its equitable sense."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Reversion of the petitioners to their parent cadre is therefore bound to have a cascading effect, prejudicing even those who are not parties before us."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for equity and prospective application.
